module.name: annotated_3d_model_equivalence_shape
module.keywords: module, shape model, product data equivalence, equivalence validation criterion, annotated 3d product model data, validation inspection requirement, validation assessment specification

abstract.li: representation of criteria for use in the equivalence validation of product shape data associated to the corresponding inspection requirements
representation of criteria for use in the equivalence validation of product shape data associated to the corresponding assessment specifications
representation of inspection results of equivalence validation of product shape data

purpose.p: Equivalence validation related standards consist of one generic resource part and six AMs(Application Modules) as follows;

ul.li: ISO 10303-62: Equivalence validation of product data;
product_data_equivalence_definition module [1];
annotated_3d_model_equivalence_criteria module [2];
annotated_3d_model_equivalence_inspection_result module;
annotated_3d_model_equivalence_shape module;
annotated_3d_model_equivalence_assembly module [3];
annotated_3d_model_equivalence_PMI module [4].

purpose.p: The structural relationship of these standards is as shown in Figure 1.

figure.title: Structural relationship between schemas and modules

purpose.p: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application module for the representation of criteria for use in the equivalence validation of product shape data that is a major constituent of annotated model 3d data. These criteria are represented together with corresponding inspection requirements which describe desirable conditions for the inspection, thresholds which describe acceptable value limit, and assessment specification on how to assess the result of inspection.

Detailed definitions of those criteria are given in 4.3, especially, overview of the criteria is given in 4.3.1 and three abstract super types to classify the criteria are given in 4.3.2, 4.3.3 and 4.3.4.

inscope.li: representation of criteria for use in the equivalence validation of product shape data associated to the corresponding inspection requirements
representation of criteria for use in the equivalence validation of product shape data associated to the corresponding assessment specifications
representation of inspection results of equivalence validation of product shape data

comparison of two models represented by either vertex point, shell based wireframe model, shell based surface model, connected edge set, connected face set, or manifold solid B-rep (boundary representation)
comparison between a model represented by point cloud data set and a model represented by connected edge set or connected face set

outscope.li: representation of general equivalence validation criteria for use in the equivalence validation of constituents of product data other than shape data
comparison of models represented by geometric set, edge based wireframe model, face based surface model, tessellated geometry, and CSG (constructive solid geometry)

definition.def: cuboid as an envelope of the shape, whose edges are alined to the cordinate axes

abbreviation.term: detected difference type name for shape criterion
accuracy type name for shape criterion
element type name for shape criterion
measured data type name for shape criterion

usage_guide.p: This annex provides some example instantiations of equivalence validation for annotated model 3d shape. Two example instances are generated for ease of understanding.

b.i: F.1 Instances for different_number_of_topological_elements and mismatch_of_faces

usage_guide.p:
Two practically important criteria,
and , are selected as examples. First, target product model data are shown. One model is a spherical shape of radius 100.0 (mm) with one face (#29) and one vertex (#34). Another model is a spherical shape of same radius with two faces (#127, #138), one edge, and one vertex (#135). The face (#29) of first model is separetaed into two faces (#127, #138) of second model.
usage_guide.note: The shapes of the data are shown in Figure F.1.
usage_guide.p: The first model is the manifold_solid_brep(#27), which consists of one closed_shell (#28), one face (#29), one vertex_loop (#33), and one vertex (#34). The first model is as follows.

The second model is the manifold_solid_brep(#125), which consists of one closed_shell (#126), two faces (#127, #138), two edge_loops (#131, #141), one edge (#134), two oriented_edges (#132, #142), and one vertex (#135). The second model is as follows.
